intro: Cracca polyzyga, commonly known as the common cracca, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, clustered yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges or along streambanks. Cracca polyzyga is also known for its aromatic properties and has been used in traditional herbal medicine.
